name: Tomatoes
keyRequirements: Full sun, consistent moisture, and well-drained soil. Requires staking or caging for support.
beginnerTips: Start with determinate varieties which are more compact and easier to manage. Ensure consistent watering to prevent blossom end rot.
advancedTips: Try grafting tomato plants onto disease-resistant rootstock. Implement a strict pruning regimen for indeterminate varieties to maximize yield.

risks.description: Susceptible to blight, fusarium wilt, and verticillium wilt.
risks.mitigation: Choose resistant varieties, practice crop rotation, and avoid wetting foliage when watering.

risks.description: Vulnerable to hornworms, aphids, and whiteflies.
risks.mitigation: Monitor regularly for pests, introduce beneficial insects, and use organic insecticidal soap if needed.

risks.description: Blossoms drop when temperatures exceed 35°C (95°F) or fall below 10°C (50°F).
risks.mitigation: Use shade cloth during extreme heat and row covers for cool periods. Choose heat-tolerant varieties in hot climates.

risks.description: Inconsistent watering can cause blossom end rot and fruit splitting.
risks.mitigation: Implement a regular watering schedule and use mulch to maintain soil moisture levels.

name: Cucumbers
keyRequirements: Full sun, consistent moisture, and warm soil. Benefits from trellising for vining varieties.
beginnerTips: Choose bush varieties for containers or small spaces. Harvest regularly to encourage continued production.
advancedTips: Try succession planting every 2-3 weeks for continuous harvest. Experiment with different trellising systems for maximum space efficiency.

risks.description: Susceptible to powdery mildew, downy mildew, and bacterial wilt.
risks.mitigation: Choose resistant varieties, ensure good air circulation, and avoid overhead watering.

risks.description: Vulnerable to cucumber beetles, aphids, and spider mites.
risks.mitigation: Use row covers until flowering, introduce beneficial insects, and monitor regularly.

risks.description: Growth slows below 15°C (60°F) and plants may be damaged below 10°C (50°F).
risks.mitigation: Use black plastic mulch to warm soil and row covers for cool nights.

risks.description: Inconsistent watering can lead to bitter fruits and reduced yields.
risks.mitigation: Maintain consistent soil moisture with regular watering and mulch.

name: Bell Peppers
keyRequirements: Full sun, warm temperatures, and well-drained soil. Benefits from support when heavy with fruit.
beginnerTips: Start with compact varieties that mature quickly. Harvest peppers at any stage of ripeness based on your preference.
advancedTips: Use shade cloth in hot climates to prevent sunscald. Implement a foliar feeding program for maximum production.

risks.description: Blossoms drop when temperatures exceed 32°C (90°F) or fall below 15°C (60°F).
risks.mitigation: Use shade cloth during extreme heat and row covers for cool periods. Choose heat-tolerant varieties in hot climates.

risks.description: Vulnerable to aphids, pepper weevils, and hornworms.
risks.mitigation: Monitor regularly for pests, introduce beneficial insects, and use organic insecticidal soap if needed.

risks.description: Susceptible to bacterial spot, phytophthora, and tobacco mosaic virus.
risks.mitigation: Choose resistant varieties, practice crop rotation, and avoid handling tobacco before working with plants.

risks.description: Often shows calcium deficiency leading to blossom end rot.
risks.mitigation: Maintain consistent soil moisture and consider calcium supplements if soil is deficient.

name: Eggplant
keyRequirements: Full sun, warm temperatures, and well-drained soil. Requires consistent heat for good production.
beginnerTips: Harvest when fruits are young and glossy for best flavor. Use pruning scissors to harvest, as stems are tough.
advancedTips: Prune to 3-4 main stems for larger fruits. In hot climates, provide afternoon shade to prevent sunscald.

risks.description: Extremely sensitive to cold; damaged below 10°C (50°F).
risks.mitigation: Wait until soil and air temperatures are consistently warm before planting. Use black plastic mulch to warm soil.

risks.description: Vulnerable to flea beetles, aphids, and spider mites.
risks.mitigation: Use row covers until flowering, introduce beneficial insects, and monitor regularly.

risks.description: Susceptible to verticillium wilt, phomopsis blight, and tobacco mosaic virus.
risks.mitigation: Choose resistant varieties, practice crop rotation, and avoid handling tobacco before working with plants.

risks.description: Poor fruit set in extreme temperatures or with inadequate pollination.
risks.mitigation: Hand pollinate flowers during extreme heat or cold. Ensure adequate bee activity.

name: Hot Peppers
keyRequirements: Full sun, warm temperatures, and well-drained soil. Thrives in hot conditions.
beginnerTips: Wear gloves when handling hot peppers. Harvest at any stage, but heat and flavor intensify as peppers ripen.
advancedTips: Slightly stressing plants (reduced watering) after fruit set can increase capsaicin levels and heat. Cross-pollination between pepper varieties can affect the heat level of saved seeds.

risks.description: Blossoms drop when temperatures exceed 35°C (95°F) or fall below 15°C (60°F).
risks.mitigation: Use shade cloth during extreme heat and row covers for cool periods. Choose appropriate varieties for your climate.

risks.description: Vulnerable to aphids, pepper weevils, and hornworms.
risks.mitigation: Monitor regularly for pests, introduce beneficial insects, and use organic insecticidal soap if needed.

risks.description: Susceptible to bacterial spot, phytophthora, and tobacco mosaic virus.
risks.mitigation: Choose resistant varieties, practice crop rotation, and avoid handling tobacco before working with plants.

risks.description: Poor fruit set in extreme temperatures or with inadequate pollination.
risks.mitigation: Hand pollinate flowers during extreme heat or cold. Ensure adequate bee activity.

name: Lettuce
keyRequirements: Cool temperatures, consistent moisture, and partial shade in hot climates. Prefers rich, well-drained soil.
beginnerTips: Sow seeds shallowly and keep soil consistently moist until germination. Harvest outer leaves as needed for a continuous supply.
advancedTips: Use succession planting every 2-3 weeks for continuous harvest. Try heat-tolerant varieties for summer growing.

risks.description: Bolts (goes to seed) quickly in hot weather above 24°C (75°F).
risks.mitigation: Plant heat-tolerant varieties in warm seasons, provide afternoon shade, and use bolt-resistant varieties.

risks.description: Vulnerable to aphids, slugs, and snails.
risks.mitigation: Use row covers, diatomaceous earth barriers for slugs, and introduce beneficial insects for aphid control.

risks.description: Susceptible to downy mildew, powdery mildew, and bottom rot.
risks.mitigation: Ensure good air circulation, avoid overhead watering, and practice crop rotation.

risks.description: Inconsistent watering can cause bitter taste and tough leaves.
risks.mitigation: Maintain consistent soil moisture with regular watering and mulch.

name: Spinach
keyRequirements: Cool temperatures, consistent moisture, and nitrogen-rich soil. Prefers full sun in cool weather, partial shade in warmer conditions.
beginnerTips: Sow seeds directly in the garden. Harvest outer leaves as needed or cut the whole plant 1 inch above soil level for regrowth.
advancedTips: Use succession planting every 2-3 weeks for continuous harvest. Try heat-tolerant varieties or spinach alternatives like New Zealand spinach for summer growing.

risks.description: Bolts quickly in hot weather above 21°C (70°F) and long daylight hours.
risks.mitigation: Plant heat-tolerant varieties in warm seasons, provide afternoon shade, and use bolt-resistant varieties.

risks.description: Vulnerable to leaf miners, aphids, and slugs.
risks.mitigation: Use row covers, introduce beneficial insects, and practice good garden sanitation.

risks.description: Susceptible to downy mildew, white rust, and fusarium wilt.
risks.mitigation: Choose resistant varieties, ensure good air circulation, and practice crop rotation.

risks.description: Often shows nitrogen deficiency with yellowing leaves.
risks.mitigation: Apply balanced organic fertilizer before planting and side-dress with nitrogen during growth.

name: Carrots
keyRequirements: Full sun to partial shade, loose, deep, well-drained soil free of rocks and clods. Consistent moisture for germination.
beginnerTips: Sow seeds directly in the garden in loose, stone-free soil. Thin seedlings to proper spacing for straight roots. Keep soil consistently moist during germination.
advancedTips: Use sand or fine compost to improve soil texture. Try growing in raised beds for deeper, straighter roots. Interplant with onions to deter carrot fly.

risks.description: Rocky or compacted soil causes forked or stunted roots.
risks.mitigation: Prepare soil deeply, removing rocks and breaking up clods. Consider raised beds with screened soil.

risks.description: Vulnerable to carrot fly, aphids, and nematodes.
risks.mitigation: Use row covers, practice crop rotation, and plant companion plants like onions and garlic.

risks.description: Susceptible to alternaria leaf blight, powdery mildew, and root rot.
risks.mitigation: Ensure good air circulation, avoid overhead watering, and practice crop rotation.

risks.description: Inconsistent watering can cause splitting and bitter taste.
risks.mitigation: Maintain consistent soil moisture with regular watering and mulch.

name: Radishes
keyRequirements: Full sun to partial shade, loose, well-drained soil. Cool temperatures for best quality.
beginnerTips: Sow seeds directly in the garden. Harvest promptly when ready to prevent pithiness. Perfect for children's gardens due to quick results.
advancedTips: Use succession planting every 7-10 days for continuous harvest. Try winter radishes like daikon for fall planting and winter harvest.

risks.description: Hot weather causes bolting and pithy, strong-flavored roots.
risks.mitigation: Plant during cool seasons, provide afternoon shade in warm weather, and harvest promptly.

risks.description: Vulnerable to flea beetles, root maggots, and aphids.
risks.mitigation: Use row covers, practice crop rotation, and maintain good garden sanitation.

risks.description: Compacted soil causes misshapen roots.
risks.mitigation: Prepare soil well, loosening to at least 6 inches depth. Add compost to improve soil structure.

risks.description: Overcrowding leads to small, underdeveloped roots.
risks.mitigation: Thin seedlings properly to recommended spacing. Avoid overseeding.

name: Broccoli
keyRequirements: Full sun, consistent moisture, and fertile, well-drained soil. Prefers cool weather for head formation.
beginnerTips: Start seeds indoors and transplant when seedlings have 4-5 true leaves. Harvest the main head when buds are tight and before flowers open.
advancedTips: After harvesting the main head, leave the plant to produce side shoots for extended harvest. Apply balanced organic fertilizer every 3-4 weeks.

risks.description: Heat causes loose, bitter heads and premature flowering. Frost damage on young plants.
risks.mitigation: Plant for harvest in cool weather. Use row covers for frost protection and shade cloth for heat protection.

risks.description: Vulnerable to cabbage worms, aphids, and flea beetles.
risks.mitigation: Use row covers, introduce beneficial insects, and apply organic Bt (Bacillus thuringiensis) for caterpillar control.

risks.description: Susceptible to clubroot, black rot, and downy mildew.
risks.mitigation: Practice crop rotation (4-year minimum for brassicas), ensure good air circulation, and maintain proper pH (6.5-7.0).

risks.description: Heavy feeder requiring significant nitrogen and calcium.
risks.mitigation: Amend soil with compost before planting and side-dress with balanced organic fertilizer during growth.

name: Cauliflower
keyRequirements: Full sun, consistent moisture, and fertile, well-drained soil. Requires cool weather and consistent temperatures for head formation.
beginnerTips: Start seeds indoors and transplant when seedlings have 4-5 true leaves. Blanch heads by tying outer leaves over the developing head when it's about 2-3 inches in diameter.
advancedTips: Maintain consistent soil moisture and temperature for best head formation. Apply balanced organic fertilizer every 3-4 weeks. Try colored varieties like purple, orange, or green (Romanesco).

risks.description: Very sensitive to temperature fluctuations. Heat causes loose, discolored heads. Cold can damage young plants.
risks.mitigation: Plant for harvest in cool weather. Use row covers for frost protection and shade cloth for heat protection.

risks.description: Vulnerable to cabbage worms, aphids, and flea beetles.
risks.mitigation: Use row covers, introduce beneficial insects, and apply organic Bt (Bacillus thuringiensis) for caterpillar control.

risks.description: Susceptible to clubroot, black rot, and downy mildew.
risks.mitigation: Practice crop rotation (4-year minimum for brassicas), ensure good air circulation, and maintain proper pH (6.5-7.0).

risks.description: Buttoning (small premature heads) due to stress or temperature fluctuations.
risks.mitigation: Maintain consistent growing conditions, avoid transplant shock, and ensure adequate nutrients and water.
